unnormalised: Question: How much does a typical grocery run cost in Mumbai?
normalised: Question: How much does a typical grocery run cost in Mumbai?

unnormalised: Well, the cost of groceries in Mumbai can vary quite a bit depending on where you shop & what you buy. For a basic weekly grocery run for a family of 4, you might be looking at spending anywhere from Rs. 3000 to Rs. 5000. This would include staples like rice, atta, dal, vegetables, milk, and some fruits. The prices can fluctuate based on the season and availability.
normalised: Well, the cost of groceries in Mumbai can vary quite a bit depending on where you shop and what you buy. For a basic weekly grocery run for a family of four, you might be looking at spending anywhere from rupee three thousand to rupee five thousand. This would include staples like rice, atta, dal, vegetables, milk, and some fruits. The prices can fluctuate based on the season and availability.

unnormalised: If you’re buying from a local market like Crawford Market or Dadar Market, you might get things a bit cheaper compared to a supermarket like D-Mart or Reliance Fresh. For example, 1 kg of tomatoes might cost Rs. 40 in a market vs. Rs. 60 in a supermarket. Imported items, obviously, are pricier. Remember to factor in things like cooking oil (approx. ₹150/litre) & spices, which can add up.
normalised: If you’re buying from a local market like Crawford Market or Dadar Market, you might get things a bit cheaper compared to a supermarket like D-Mart or Reliance Fresh. For example, one kilogram of tomatoes might cost rupee forty in a market versus rupee sixty in a supermarket. Imported items, obviously, are pricier. Remember to factor in things like cooking oil (approximately rupee one hundred and fifty per liter) and spices, which can add up.

unnormalised: Also, keep an eye out for deals & discounts. Many stores offer weekly specials or loyalty programs that can help you save money. Some online grocery platforms also give attractive discounts. But beware of "convenience fees" and min order amounts. A small purchase for, say, ₹200 might incur an extra ₹50 in delivery charges. Plan your purchases to maximize value.
normalised: Also, keep an eye out for deals and discounts. Many stores offer weekly specials or loyalty programs that can help you save money. Some online grocery platforms also give attractive discounts. But beware of "convenience fees" and minimum order amounts. A small purchase for, say, rupee two hundred might incur an extra rupee fifty in delivery charges. Plan your purchases to maximize value.
